subject: Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... True, QS with the wrong implementation cannot.  But QS treated phonemically can: I do not believe there has ever been a QS user who tried to find a letter
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:

>(There are also splits, where a lexical set divides into two
>different pronunciations, but QS just can't handle those at all.)

True, QS with the wrong implementation cannot. But QS treated
phonemically can: I do not believe there has ever been a QS user who
tried to find a letter for a sound and failed. The problem has been
the reverse: we find too many letters that work. There are two
proposals now to solve this:
1. do not use letters for sounds not found in your accent.
2. follow a complex set of rules to simulate Upper Class British
English.
My bias is towards number 1.

>> it is just one letter out of 6 in one word out of 50 and is
unimportant.
>Au contraire. Hundreds of thousands of words are affected.

I'm sure you have a basis for this figure even though it so very
strongly resembles a complete guess. It would perhaps be better to
show us an Australian and Non-Australian version of the same text side
by side as I have done with US vs RP here:
http://quickscript.tonygrahn.com/spellcomparison.html
Even (semi-)phonetic QS demonstrably does not produce readability
problems. If you have a non-contrived typical prose example to the
contrary then it will prove otherwise. If you are incapable of
producing such a thing, I'll be happy to make it for you with pieces
you provide. But merely denying a demonstrated fact repeatedly is
hardly compelling.


>Not at all. A huge number of old mergers (meet/meat, vain/vein) are
>disposed of, as well as gobs of pointless irregularities that have never
>meant anything to anybody.

Your proposed treatment of QS may get rid of some or many. Phonemic QS
disposes of all TO irregularities.


>> - One has the absurd situation of answering the question "why do I
>> spell it thus" with "because TO does and TO does it because in 13th
>> century London the queen had a lisp".

>(That story is about Spanish, not English, and it's not true anyway.
>Just sayin'.)

Living in Spain for two years, oddly I was aware of this. But as it
is untrue of both nations then the myth applies equally to the English ;->
The obvious point of my witty anecdote is that you end up with QS
spellings that are ultimately justified by absurd TO spellings. This
defeats the purpose of having QS at all. It is a fine thing to cherish
the history of the English language but it's preposterous to burden
the present language with spelling from the past and absolutely
ridiculous to carry those burdens into a reform project (ie QS).


>> - There are exceptions to any such rules that will cause QS users to
>> produce exactly the wrong result: if a person merging [I] and [i] is
>> told to "use #26 for words of that sound that have a TO letter 'i' in
>> the spelling and use #27 for all others with that sound" then they
>> will spell "busy" and "bean" with the same letter. in this case "busy"
>> with [i] something not done in RP or anywhere. But if you reveres the
>> instructions the problem now exists with "bean"

>So it does, by Goerge [sic]. I don't know what anyone can do about that.
>If you can't hear the difference, you're going to make misteaks.

(A rebuttal consisting of nothing but sarcastic references to a
typo is rather weak don't you think?)
The writer's potential mistakes are solely a result of a complex
rule about when to use which letter *non-phonetically*. Without such
rules, such mistakes are a priori impossible. You would be introducing
into QS rules like "I before E except after C..." which, aside from
being preposterous, lead inherently to errors by writers because of
their exceptions. Since the rules you propose for QS refer to TO
spelling, they inherit all of TO's spelling exceptions and all the
errors this results in.
But when treating QS as essentially phonemic as intended, this kind
of problem does not exist.



>> Still it looks like Lexical set's are quite usable in a solution,
>At least we are no longer talking about "phonomes". :-)

"Phonomes"(sic) still make more sense than the proposed Lexical Set
use if only because phonemic mapping is in fact what is currently used
successfully. So far the only aspects of Lexical Sets shown to be
useable would be to clarify the phoneme for each letter to persons of
different accents (which, of course, is a neat accomplishment)
But the complex proposal for mapping Lexical Sets to QS letters and
adding a battery of spelling rules seems only to be an immensely
convoluted way to try to have all writers spell words as Kingsley Read
would and effectively do little more than map QS letters directly to
TO letters and letter pairs. Perhaps Lexical Sets can be applied
further in someway not yet described but the above mentioned approach
is unworkable I fear.
